title-group.article-title: SAVINGS INSTITUTIONS THAT COUNT FOR SMALL AND MICRO ENTERPRISES: THE CASE OF URBAN KENYA

abstract.p: Lack of credit to small and micro enterprises (SMEs) has been seen as one of the constraints hindering their growth and expansion. Various credit programs and policy measures were therefore formulated to direct credit to this sector. However, savings, although usually forgotten, is one of their most important financial needs. This paper, using a cross-sectional survey of urban SME proprietors in Kenya, empirically investigates their savings pattern by analysing the choices of financial institutions they save with. Its findings show that although the informal financial sector (IFS) counts more, both the IFS and the formal financial sector (FFS) matter in terms of mobilising their savings given the significant proportion that save in both. However, it is banks, especially the post office savings bank (POSB) due mainly to its affordable minimum savings account balance, rotating savings and credit associations (RoSCAs), own savings at home/place of work, mutual assistance groups (MAGs), and accumulating savings and credit associations (ASCRAs) in that order, that are the saving institutions that count. Further results reveal that their decisions to save with a given sector are influenced by specific factors, which motivate them to save with institutions that compel them to save, restrict access to their savings and those which provide unfettered access. The paper concludes that their coexistence is healthy and their operating environment should be enhanced because they meet different savings needs of SME proprietors.
